text: When you see a team that is motivated, that is building something like they're really excited about, I mean just the inertia, the quality, it's like a whole different game where when you see a team that's sort of down and out and they've really been hitting their head against the wall for a long time, sometimes they just need a change of scene, a change of pace, and they get to a much better situation. So my honest answer is, yeah, it's the, when do you run out of steam is usually the question.
speaker: Noam Lovinsky
context: Lenny asks how long you should stick with a project that isn't going well before deciding to move on. Noam explains that while most projects and early companies fail due to lack of stamina rather than running out of money, the key indicator for when to pivot or kill a project is when the team loses motivation and energy. He emphasizes that high-ambiguity projects require tremendous faith and stamina to succeed.
vocabulary_highlights: hitting their head against the wall
text_ko: 정말 신나서 뭔가를 만들고 있는 팀을 보면 관성(inertia)도 그렇고 결과물의 퀄리티도 완전히 달라요. 반대로 오랫동안 벽에 부딪혀서 기운 빠진 팀은 분위기 자체가 처져 있어서, 그런 팀들은 때로는 단순히 환경이나 속도를 바꿔주는 것만으로도 훨씬 나아져요. 솔직히 말하면 보통은 결국 언제 기운이 다하느냐가 관건이에요.
text_zh: 当你看到一个团队特别有干劲，在做一个他们真正兴奋的项目时，那种势头啊，那个质量啊，完全就是另一个层面的东西。但如果你看到一个团队垂头丧气的，已经撞南墙撞了很久了，有时候他们就是需要换个环境，换个节奏，这样就能进入一个更好的状态。所以我的真心话就是，关键问题通常是，你什么时候会没劲儿了。
text_es: Cuando ves un equipo que está motivado, que está construyendo algo que realmente les emociona, o sea, la inercia, la calidad... es como un juego completamente diferente. Pero cuando ves un equipo que está como decaído y que lleva mucho tiempo dándose contra la pared, a veces lo que necesitan es simplemente cambiar de aires, cambiar el ritmo, y llegan a una situación mucho mejor. Entonces mi respuesta honesta es, sí, se trata de... cuándo se te acaba la gasolina, esa suele ser la pregunta clave.

text: I think that one important lesson from that is, no one can be a bystander on product strategy. Just because you've got product in your title doesn't mean you're the only one that should be thinking about product strategy certainly at that level. Certainly not in engineering. The CFO, the head of people, everyone needs to have a seat at the table when it comes to product strategy, what the company's doing and what they're going to do to grow out of the situation that they're in.
speaker: Noam Lovinsky
context: Lenny asks about lessons from Noam's time at Thumbtack during their turnaround period. Noam explains that when companies face challenges like negative growth, the entire leadership team must unite around product strategy rather than leaving it solely to the product team. He emphasizes that at the leadership level, cross-functional collaboration becomes critical for navigating difficult periods.
vocabulary_highlights: have a seat at the table
text_ko: 제가 보기엔 그 일에서 얻은 중요한 교훈 중 하나가 제품 전략(product strategy)에 대해서는 누구도 방관자가 될 수 없다는 거예요. 직함에 '프로덕트'가 들어간다고 해서 그 수준의 제품 전략을 혼자서만 생각해야 한다는 건 절대 아니에요. 특히 엔지니어링 쪽은 더더욱 그렇지 않아요. 최고재무책임자(CFO), 인사 책임자(Head of People) 등 모든 사람이 제품 전략과 회사가 현재 처한 상황에서 벗어나 성장하기 위한 계획에 대해 의사결정 테이블에 함께 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得这里有个很重要的教训，就是在产品战略(product strategy)这件事上，谁都不能当旁观者。不是说你的职位里带个"产品"两个字，你就是唯一需要考虑产品战略的人，尤其是在那个层面上。工程团队更不用说了。CFO、人事负责人，所有人在讨论产品战略的时候都得有发言权，都得参与进来，讨论公司要做什么，怎么从现在的困境中突围出去。
text_es: Creo que una lección importante de eso es que nadie puede quedarse al margen cuando se trata de estrategia de producto. Que tengas "producto" en tu puesto no significa que seas el único que debe pensar en la estrategia de producto, especialmente a ese nivel. Y menos aún en ingeniería. El CFO, el head de recursos humanos, todos necesitan tener voz y voto cuando hablamos de estrategia de producto, de lo que está haciendo la empresa y de cómo van a salir adelante de la situación en la que están.

text: If you're a large organization and you do some performance management process twice a year and you're 0 to 1 incubator, you've already killed it. It's the wrong incentive. Smart, good people, even if they're not trying to, they end up kind of gaming things towards the incentive system. And so think long and hard about that.
speaker: Noam Lovinsky
context: Lenny asks for advice on creating effective startup-within-a-startup initiatives at large companies. Noam discusses the critical importance of designing proper incentive systems for innovation teams. He explains that traditional corporate performance management cycles are fundamentally incompatible with early-stage product development, which requires different timeframes and success metrics than established business operations.
text_ko: 대규모 조직이고 연 2회 하는 성과 관리 프로세스 (performance management process)를 운영하면서 0에서 1을 만드는 인큐베이터 (0 to 1 incubator) 역할을 하고 있다면 이미 그걸 망쳐버린 거예요. 잘못된 인센티브 구조예요. 똑똑하고 유능한 사람들도 일부러 그러는 게 아니라도 결국 인센티브에 맞춰 시스템을 조작하거나 이득을 보려고 게임하듯 행동하게 돼요 (gaming the system). 그러니까 그 점을 충분히, 진지하게 고민해 보세요.
text_zh: 如果你是个大公司，每年搞两次绩效管理(performance management)，但你做的是从零到一的孵化项目(0 to 1 incubator)，那基本上就死定了。这个激励机制完全搞反了。那些聪明能干的人，哪怕他们不是故意的，最后也会想办法钻激励体系的空子。所以这事儿你得好好想想。
text_es: Si eres una organización grande y haces algún proceso de evaluación de desempeño dos veces al año, pero estás en modo incubadora de 0 a 1, ya la mataste. Es el incentivo equivocado. La gente inteligente y buena, aunque no sea su intención, termina jugando el sistema hacia donde están los incentivos. Así que piénsatelo muy bien.

text: Growth masks all problems. You don't really have a, I think, true understanding of what is working well and what is not working well when you have incredible growth. And at Thumbtack, it had incredible growth for quite some time, but it was essentially burning through a lot of demand. It was just dropping a lot of demand on the floor because there wasn't sufficient liquidity on the supply side to really meet that demand.
speaker: Noam Lovinsky
context: Lenny asks about lessons from Noam's experience at Thumbtack during their challenging period when growth went negative. Noam explains how rapid growth can hide fundamental business problems that only become apparent when growth slows or reverses. At Thumbtack specifically, strong user acquisition was masking supply-side liquidity issues in their marketplace.
text_ko: 성장은 모든 문제를 가려요. 엄청나게 성장하고 있으면 무엇이 잘되고 있고 무엇이 잘못되고 있는지 진짜로 제대로 알기 어렵거든요. Thumbtack도 한동안 엄청난 성장을 했는데, 사실 많은 수요(demand)를 소진하는 식이었어요. 공급 측면(supply)에 충분한 유동성(liquidity)이 없어서 그 수요를 제대로 충족시키지 못했고, 결국 많은 수요가 그냥 바닥에 떨어져 버렸어요.
text_zh: 增长会掩盖所有问题。我觉得当你有惊人增长的时候，你根本搞不清楚到底哪些地方做得好，哪些地方有问题。Thumbtack有段时间增长确实很猛，但其实是在白白浪费很多需求。因为供给端流动性(supply side liquidity)不够，根本满足不了那么多需求，所以很多需求就这么白白流失了。
text_es: El crecimiento tapa todos los problemas. Cuando tienes un crecimiento increíble, la verdad es que no tienes una idea clara de qué está funcionando bien y qué no. Y en Thumbtack, tuvimos un crecimiento impresionante durante bastante tiempo, pero básicamente estábamos quemando mucha demanda. Se nos estaba cayendo muchísima demanda porque no teníamos suficiente liquidez del lado de la oferta para realmente satisfacer esa demanda.

text: I always tell people I feel like I'm an IC trapped in a manager's body sometimes. Fundamentally, I like to build, that's why I do this. I like to make things. And so sometimes the more fun way to make things is to start something and sometimes the better way to make things in the situation that I'm in is to try to support teams and lead through teams.
speaker: Noam Lovinsky
context: Lenny asks about Noam's diverse career experiences across different types of product challenges. Noam explains his motivation for changing roles and companies frequently, describing his core drive to build and create products. An IC refers to an individual contributor - someone who does hands-on work rather than managing others. Noam describes the tension between wanting to build directly versus leading teams to build.
vocabulary_highlights: IC trapped in a manager's body
text_ko: 사람들에게 항상 가끔은 매니저의 몸에 갇힌 개인 기여자(Individual Contributor, IC) 같다고 말해요. 본질적으로 저는 뭔가를 만드는 걸 좋아해서 이 일을 해요. 그래서 때로는 직접 뭔가를 시작해서 만드는 게 더 재밌고, 반대로 지금 제 위치에서는 팀을 지원하고 팀을 통해 이끄는 게 더 나은 방법일 때도 있어요.
text_zh: 我经常跟别人说，有时候感觉自己就像是一个被困在管理者身体里的个人贡献者(IC)。说到底，我就是喜欢搭建东西，这就是我做这行的原因。我喜欢创造。所以有时候创造东西最有意思的方式就是从零开始做一个项目，但有时候在我现在的位置上，更好的创造方式是去支持团队，通过团队来实现目标。
text_es: Siempre le digo a la gente que a veces me siento como un colaborador individual (IC) atrapado en el cuerpo de un gerente. En el fondo, me gusta construir cosas, por eso hago esto. Me gusta crear. Y a veces la forma más divertida de crear es empezar algo desde cero, y otras veces la mejor manera de crear en la situación en la que estoy es tratar de apoyar a los equipos y liderar a través de ellos.

text: When you're thinking about career opportunities and what job to take, it's really, really hard to sniff out really well in a high degree of certainty like success. I think that having a good nose for people and the sort of people that you can be successful with is something that you can develop. What I found is I always try to prioritize putting myself in positions that are going to cause a lot of growth and learning.
speaker: Noam Lovinsky
context: Lenny asks for general career advice based on Noam's successful journey across multiple companies. Noam explains that while it's difficult to predict which companies or roles will be successful, you can develop skills for evaluating people and teams. He emphasizes choosing roles that will stretch you and create significant personal growth, even when that growth involves discomfort.
text_ko: 커리어 기회나 어떤 직업을 선택할지 고민할 때, 그 일이 정말 성공할지 높은 확률로 잘 가려내는 건 정말 어렵다고 생각해요. 사람을 잘 알아보는 감각, 즉 함께 일했을 때 성공할 수 있는 사람을 판별하는 능력은 충분히 키울 수 있는 거라고 봐요. 저는 항상 성장과 배움을 많이 가져다줄 자리나 상황에 자신을 두는 걸 우선시하려고 해요.
text_zh: 当你在考虑职业机会、选择工作的时候，想要很准确地嗅出成功的机会，真的是特别特别难的。我觉得培养对人的敏锐嗅觉，能看出哪些人可以和你一起成功，这个能力是可以慢慢培养的。我发现我总是会优先把自己放在那些能让我快速成长和学到东西的位置上。
text_es: Cuando estás pensando en oportunidades profesionales y qué trabajo agarrar, es súper difícil detectar con mucha certeza el éxito que vas a tener. Creo que desarrollar buen ojo para la gente y el tipo de personas con las que puedes triunfar es algo que se puede trabajar. Lo que he visto es que siempre trato de priorizarme en posiciones que me van a generar mucho crecimiento y aprendizaje.
